column4: i want to upgrade from 6.10 to 9.04.. i have 3 iso's on my computer.. i mount them, i use the upgrading command, but nothing happens. My iso's are: 7.04,8.04 and 9.04. What should I do?
you need to use the alternate isos
try replacing /cdrom with where you mount the iso
if you don't mount the iso to /cdrom then it won't work
its wherever you mount it. you could have mounted it literally anywhere so there is no definitive answer
i  do this: < mount -o loop iso_location /media/cdrom0 > then <gksu "sh /media/cdrom0/cdromupgrade" >
i hope you didnt literally type iso_location. did you?
no .. of course not :P
good. well if you mount the iso to /media/cdrom0 you should be able to check it exists if you browse to the folder and view the contents
i am able to do that.. i can browse the files
it actually get's me an icon on the desktop that i double click
ok cool then use terminal to cd to the location of the file you need to launch instead of specifying the absolute locations
you can then use: gksudo ./upgrade   or whatever it is
it is not possible to do this with the desktop iso. it MUST be the alternative iso

there is a live desktop cd and the alternative that installs in a text based environment and is much faster

the upgrade documentation clearly states you need the alternate iso to upgrade offline. you cannot doo it if the isos you have are the live desktop ones
